Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Mechanism and kinetics of catalytic ozonation for elimination of organic compounds with spinel-type CuAl<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and its precursor.

AbstractText: CuAl<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> based mixed oxides were used as heterogeneous catalysts for ozone activation to degrade organics in aqueous solution. The solids were thoroughly characterized by SEM/EDS, N<sub>2</sub> physisorption, XRD, FTIR, Pyridine-FTIR, TEM and XPS. We demonstrated that the solid precursor calcined at 300 °C exhibited the best catalytic ozonation activity with respect to CuAl<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> spinel phase obtained at higher temperatures. Such performance was attributed to the better textural properties and a higher density of active sites (hydroxyl groups and Lewis acidity). Specifically, the mixed oxide/O<sub>3</sub> process allows to reach a near complete color removal of the dye solution (100 mg L<sup>-1</sup>) in 25 min at neutral pH. Corresponding reaction rate value was measured at 0.112 min<sup>-1</sup> and was clearly higher compared with the single oxide ozonation process (0.071 min<sup>-1</sup> for CuO/O<sub>3</sub> and 0.074 min<sup>-1</sup> for Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/O<sub>3</sub>). Then, we proposed that such catalytic performance was related to a synergistic function between ≡Cu<sup>2+</sup> and ≡Al<sup>3+</sup>, which took part of a mechanism of radical formation. In such mechanism, present ≡Al<sup>3+</sup> could act as a reservoir for surface active sites such as hydroxyl groups and Lewis acid sites, while ≡Cu<sup>2+</sup> could provide the possibility of electron transfer with ozone for the enhancement of radical generation. We suggested that the interaction between chemisorbed ozone and surface hydroxyl groups initially stabilized on ≡Al<sup>3+</sup> initiated the generation of reactive radical species. This interaction led as well to the formation of surface adsorbed HO and few O<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> on ≡Cu<sup>2+</sup> Lewis acid sites. Besides, the interfacial redox reaction with ozone is favored by the presence of ≡Cu<sup>2+</sup> following the sequence of ≡Cu<sup>2+</sup>/≡Cu<sup>+</sup>/≡Cu<sup>2+</sup> redox cycle.
